0.87.text:
The first story
that I wanted to share

2.24.text:
of this new work is a
story about Tiger Sharks.

4.97.text:
Now, Tiger Sharks if
you read the literature

7.97.text:
are described as the
most dangerous sharks

11.71.text:
They are considered the
second most dangerous species

14.45.text:
of shark overall
after The Great White.

17.28.text:
They've certainly been
portrayed as mindless monsters

20.72.text:
but in reality the
cutting edge science

23.76.text:
that's being done right
now is showing that these

25.73.text:
are animals that actually
have a pretty high degree

27.53.text:
of cognition and they
have the ability to learn

32.03.text:
Can't get into
all that right now

33.60.text: but this is some of the stuff

35.07.text:
that will be published I
think in the time ahead.

37.87.text:
They're also one of the most
versatile species of sharks.

40.71.text:
One day they'll be hunting
in a thousand meters

43.64.text:
of deep Pacific water
and the very next day

45.91.text:
they'll be in a marina
looking for fish scraps

50.65.text:
When they are born tiger
sharks look like this,

53.25.text:
they have this amazingly
stunning pattern of stripes

56.99.text:
which off course is where
they get the name from,

59.39.text:
the tiger like stripes that
they have on their body.

62.06.text:
This was a neonate just a few
days old that I photographed

67.13.text:
Those stripes begin
to fade as the animal

69.27.text:
gets a little bit older and
they're not quite as vivid

73.51.text: But the in the 20 years or so,

76.31.text:
I've been diving
for almost 40 years,

77.74.text:
but for about 20
years of my career,

80.01.text:
I was very interested
in finding tiger sharks

84.12.text:
I would do trips to various
places but never really

86.39.text:
found them in any predictable
way but a number of years ago

90.02.text:
a buddy of mine that ran
or runs a dive business

92.36.text:
out of Palm Beach Florida
discovered a place

94.53.text:
in the Bahamas, in
the Northern Bahamas

97.80.text: And this is an aerial view,

99.27.text:
I used the National Geographic
blimp to do a low altitude

103.24.text:
And this is a place, it's
sort of a sandy, shallow,

106.87.text:
sand flat area in the
Northern Bahamas where

108.77.text:
these animals congregate,
you'll find on any given day,

112.48.text: a dozen or more of them.

113.75.text:
So we see a bunch of
these big ol' tigers

116.22.text:
hanging out behind the boat,
perfect day to go swimming.

120.09.text:
This is what it looks
like underwater,

124.26.text:
You can swim down about
maybe 20 feet or so

128.23.text:
and find yourself in the company
of these big tiger sharks.

132.10.text:
Many of these are between
12 and 14 feet in length.

136.10.text: And they'll come up very close,

138.34.text:
they'll give you some
great closeup encounters

141.54.text:
not using any cages
here or anything.

143.81.text:
And it's a pretty
extraordinary thing

146.61.text:
to be able to see
these animals like this

149.82.text: and to be in their presence.

151.85.text:
The first time I did
it, my heart was racing

154.25.text: through my chest but over time,

156.16.text:
you never fully
let your guard down

158.19.text:
but I think you relax
at least a little bit

162.36.text:
Part of the approach
that I took this time

165.33.text:
when I was out there
for this latest story

166.87.text:
in the magazine was, to
try to show these animals,

169.84.text:
a little bit like their
terrestrial namesake,

172.81.text:
to try to make pictures that
looked a little bit like

175.54.text:
a tiger on land maybe
sneaking its way through

178.64.text:
the grasses of
India or something,

180.65.text:
channeling my inner
Steve Winter here.

183.68.text:
But the difference was
off course I wasn't

187.12.text: on the back of an elephant.

188.65.text:
So you have be eye to
eye with these guys.

192.39.text:
And that's what some
people like to do,

194.73.text:
you like to just have
a little conversation

196.06.text:
with tiger sharks,
just "how was your day?",

199.27.text:
kinda have a little chat
here like this diver's doing.

202.17.text:
Actually this is showing
the fact that ecotourism

206.97.text:
has really prospered
in this place,

208.81.text:
ever since the discovery
of Tiger Beach,

211.44.text:
a number of companies
have sprung up.

213.05.text:
Ecotourism dive companies
that will get you out there

215.88.text:
and get you in the
company of tiger sharks,

220.52.text:
Sometimes it can
get a little dicey,

221.99.text:
especially when you get
multiple sharks coming around

224.62.text: but, in my experiences out there

226.29.text:
in the weeks that I've
spent out in Tiger Beach,

228.09.text:
I have to say that they
were all very well behaved,

230.53.text:
generally well behaved
for the most part.

232.77.text:
Occasionally, they'll
try to eat my camera,

235.30.text:
like this one did
right here but,

238.14.text:
once they realize that
it's not especially tasty,

240.77.text: they sort of just move on.

242.68.text:
And during my time out
there on these recent trips,

246.41.text:
I also wanted to move
away from those shallow,

250.98.text:
And try to photograph
tiger sharks

254.72.text: Because they hang out there too.

256.12.text: Lots of tigers in the Bahamas

257.89.text:
and I wanted to see if I
could get the lord of reef

260.56.text:
sort of patrolling
over these sponges

263.26.text: and corals that we see here.

265.16.text:
Or to look at the behaviors
of multiple animals.

268.73.text:
We do see a lot of different
sharks here and there

271.57.text:
there definitely seems to
be sort of some hierarchy,

277.34.text:
It's not fully understood,
I mean to some degree,

279.81.text: it's usually the big shark wins,

281.31.text:
the other one usually
goes the other way but,

283.28.text:
there is something
going on there

284.88.text:
that I think we'll
figure out in time.

286.99.text: And we see this a lot too.

290.32.text:
Sharks with hooks
in their mouth.

291.86.text:
And it's not relegated
only to tiger sharks,

295.03.text:
pretty much everywhere
I go in the world,

296.96.text:
you see evidence of
fishing pressure.

299.27.text:
This tiger had two
big hooks in its mouth

301.57.text:
but we see jewelry
as it's often called

304.20.text:
on many sharks all
over the world.

309.14.text:
that seems to be
happening everywhere.

310.84.text:
And thanks to a grant from the
National Geographic Society

315.28.text:
we were also able to fund
some research out there.

318.22.text:
This is, on the
right of the frame,

320.19.text:
this is Dr. Neil Hammerschlag
from the University of Miami

323.69.text:
who's been studying tiger
sharks in this region

325.79.text:
for some time and one
of the ways he does this

328.36.text:
is he built this special
platform that can submerge

331.46.text: just below the back of our boat,

333.03.text:
you tie it up to the
back of the boat,

334.50.text:
and then he brings
a Tiger shark in

337.30.text:
and I'm not sure his
insurance company

340.17.text:
but nonetheless,
what could go wrong.

342.88.text:
And he brings it in and
then they work up the shark,

349.68.text:
But the standard
procedure has always been

352.92.text:
to measure the shark,
take a DNA clipping,

355.79.text:
maybe a fin clipping
for DNA sample,

362.73.text: they implant a body cavity tag

364.33.text:
so they can track
the animal over time.

366.23.text:
But some of the newest
research is ultrasound work

370.40.text:
that's going on right here
and that's what this woman

372.24.text:
researcher is doing in the
center of the frame here

375.44.text:
Because Tiger Beach,
it's been discovered,

377.78.text: seems to be a maternity ward.

379.65.text:
Most of the sharks there
are females and many of them

382.21.text:
are pregnant and that
shallow warm water

386.49.text:
So they're doing these
sonograms that they can keep

390.32.text:
a videograph of and they can
see how many pups are inside

394.76.text:
and then the tagging data will
show where the animal goes,

397.16.text:
they don't actually have
their pups in the Bahamas,

398.97.text:
they're going up into Northern
Florida, Georgia water,

403.34.text:
this would be a very
critical habitat,

405.24.text:
we might want to
protect in the future.

407.04.text:
And we also did
some crittercam work.

409.54.text: I think most of you might know

412.45.text:
where they attach cameras and
various scientific instruments

416.62.text:
to animals and let
them sort of carry it

420.15.text:
This was the first time
that one had been attached

423.96.text:
So this is Neil Hammerschlag
after he just put that

426.63.text:
fin clamp on the
tiger shark here

428.79.text:
and he's sort of checking
it, making sure it's alright.

430.63.text:
And then off it goes for
the better part of the day

433.37.text:
recording both video and
all kinds of other data.

437.07.text: And here we can see the shark

438.57.text:
sort of swimming around
a little shark cameraman.

440.41.text:
Here just another example of
an animal taking our jobs.

444.48.text: But in any case, what this data,

449.55.text:
I mean they only did it a little

451.68.text:
but it did yield some
interesting things.

453.39.text:
Most of the ecotourism

455.45.text:
felt that they knew exactly

They go in from one

459.39.text:
and just staying on

461.39.text:
But the crittercam
showed that in between

464.03.text:
some of those visits, they're

466.73.text:
We don't quite know exactly

468.83.text:
but clearly there's
a lot more going on

471.04.text:
in these animal's
lives than we realize.

behind the scenes,

just give you a sense of what

801.07.text:
Makos attack from below,
they have that big eye

that allows them to see very

808.34.text: and to be able to look up

810.94.text:
And then when they see a

they'll often bite the

whether it's Tuna or Marlin

820.25.text:
and then wait for it to

822.02.text:

And those are the things

827.23.text:

I used to have these split

835.10.text:
like a fish and so now
I've gone with something

837.54.text:
that like two big two

839.84.text:
something that looks

But yeah everything about

It's really built like

Just pure muscle and

but what I've learned

I mean that's just

and I look at my assistant

they don't stick

you have to sort of be

because I don't want

but for the most part,

they will come in and

1007.61.text:
But these are animals

1012.58.text:
Meaning that they can

It was Brooke Runnette

1016.85.text:
who termed the

1018.95.text:
These are hot sharks because

1021.22.text:
in their body and because

1023.22.text:
into colder water and feed

1026.56.text:

A mako shark can swim at

And you gotta remember,
that underwater,

the medium is much

a 100 miles an

in San Diego I wanted

Because there's still a

for this kind of thing,
when you consider

1149.98.text:

1152.32.text:
I don't really think
there is a benefit

1154.29.text:

and, I watched them drag

looking like a slayed

1197.70.text:
And I recognize that not
everyone will get to see

1200.87.text:
a shark underwater,
probably the way

1207.57.text:
We can appreciate lions and
grizzly bears and tigers

1212.01.text:
But underwater these
animals are just slaughtered

1213.28.text: and often with little regard so.

1215.11.text:
My hope is that photography
can sort of move

1217.98.text:
that forward a little bit in
terms of some appreciation.

1221.42.text:
And one of the other
things I wanted to do

1223.09.text:
with this story,
with video actually

1226.59.text: was to show the speed of a Mako

1230.43.text:
So with the grant from
the Geographic Society,

1235.73.text:
at Woods Hole
Oceanographic, we designed

1237.37.text:
a tow camera system, I
found an industrial camera

1240.54.text: that shot at very high speed.

1242.34.text:
I could shoot at
720 frames a second.

1244.54.text:
We built this tow
camera, and I worked

1246.71.text:
with a New Zealand's
champion sports fisherman

1249.18.text:
who fished for marlin
and he would rig

1251.38.text:
a mullet bait, type
of fish called mullet

1253.82.text:
and trail it behind
the boat for marlin

1255.25.text:
but he said often times
Makos would attack it.

1257.46.text:
So I was there for
a couple of weeks

1258.69.text:
but I only got one day
where I could do it.

1260.59.text:
So I've got a two minute
video with no sound

1262.89.text:
but I'll just have a look
at that and show you,

1265.90.text:
this is the first time
this has ever been seen

1267.97.text:
of a Mako in high speed
attacking something, a mullet.

1280.91.text:
Everything that you're
gonna see here happened

1285.22.text:
But we're shooting so fast
that we can play it back

1288.42.text:
at normal speed and
it's slow motion.

1291.02.text:
But it was fascinating
to see this animal

1294.76.text:
he sort of put his
pectoral fins back

1297.56.text:
in a very hydrodynamic way
almost trying to use his weight

1300.46.text: and the speed to break it off.

1302.57.text:
The boat was travelling
at about eight knots.

1304.34.text:
And he had no trouble
off course firing up

1307.44.text:
and going in and
grabbing that bait.

1310.14.text:
But it was interesting
to see that behavior,

1311.81.text:
I think researchers, I haven't
showed this to scientists yet

1314.21.text:
but I think they'll
be interested to see

1315.81.text: this form that the Mako assumes

1318.05.text: once he's bitten into the prey.

1324.32.text:
Just a truly remarkable
predator for sure.

1339.64.text:
They can sort of detach
their jaws like a Great White

1343.64.text:
I hadn't realized that but
you can see it coming out.

1345.04.text:
So pretty amazing
behavior from Mako sharks

1347.21.text:
shot at 720 frames
per second well,
